title: Randomized Complete Block Design (RCBD) with Blocking
text:
In the realm of experimental design, Complete Block Designs (CBDs) play a pivotal role in controlling the effects of nuisance factors, thereby enhancing the precision of treatment comparisons. By organizing experimental units into blocks that share similar characteristics, CBDs effectively reduce variability stemming from these extraneous factors. This structured approach not only refines the efficiency of experiments but also ensures more accurate and reliable analyses.


Imagine you are testing different fertilizers on crops spread across a large farm. The farm has sections with varying soil types, sunlight exposure, and moisture levels. Without controlling for these variations, it would be challenging to discern the true effect of each fertilizer. By grouping plots with similar soil types into blocks, you can more precisely compare the performance of fertilizers within each homogeneous group, minimizing the confounding influence of soil variability.
This lecture delves into the structure, applications, and analysis of Complete Block Designs, with a focus on Randomized Complete Block Designs (RCBDs) and their generalizations. We will explore theoretical underpinnings, practical implementations using R, and advanced topics to provide a comprehensive understanding tailored for graduate statistics students.

title: Randomized Complete Block Design (RCBD) with Blocking
text:
Objectives

Define and distinguish between complete and incomplete block designs.
Explore the structure and application of Randomized Complete Block Designs (RCBDs).
Perform Analysis of Variance (ANOVA) for RCBDs and assess the efficiency of blocking.
Understand general complete block designs and their applications.
Implement complete block designs in R and interpret the results.
Reinforce concepts with exercises covering numerical examples, conceptual understanding, and mathematical proofs.
Explore advanced mathematical derivations and proofs in the Appendix.

title: Randomized Complete Block Design (RCBD) with Blocking
text:
What Are Complete Block Designs?
Complete Block Designs (CBDs) are experimental designs where each block contains all the treatments being tested. This ensures that every treatment is applied in each block, allowing for direct comparisons under similar conditions.

Block: A group of experimental units that are similar in some aspect and expected to yield comparable responses.
Complete Block: Each block includes every treatment exactly once.


Example
In a clinical trial comparing drug treatments across different hospitals, each hospital represents a block. By administering all treatments in each hospital, you account for hospital-specific factors, such as patient demographics and care protocols, ensuring that treatment effects are evaluated consistently.

title: Randomized Complete Block Design (RCBD) with Blocking
text:
Randomized Complete Block Designs (RCBDs)
RCBDs are a specific type of CBD where treatments are randomly assigned within each block. This randomness ensures that the assignment of treatments is free from bias and that any differences observed are attributable to the treatments rather than systematic variations.
Characteristics of RCBDs:

The number of experimental units in each block equals the number of treatments.
Each treatment appears exactly once per block.
Treatments are assigned randomly within each block.

Analogy: Think of RCBDs as seating arrangements in a classroom where each row (block) must contain one student from each house (treatments). By randomly assigning students to seats within rows, you ensure that no particular house has an advantage in any row.

title: Randomized Complete Block Design (RCBD) with Blocking
text:
General Complete Block Designs
Beyond RCBDs, General Complete Block Designs allow for multiple observations or replicates of treatments within each block. This is particularly useful when interaction effects between treatments and blocks are anticipated.
Features:

A treatment is replicated \(s > 1\) times within a block.
Facilitates the detection of interactions between treatments and blocking factors.

Example: In a clinical trial, if a treatment needs to be administered multiple times within each hospital ward (block) to account for ward-specific factors, a general complete block design would be appropriate.

title: Randomized Complete Block Design (RCBD) with Blocking
text:
Model and Assumptions
The statistical model for an RCBD can be expressed as:
\[
Y_{hi} = \mu + \theta_h + \tau_i + \epsilon_{hi}
\]
Where:

\(Y_{hi}\): Response variable for treatment \(i\) in block \(h\).
\(\mu\): Overall mean.
\(\theta_h\): Effect of block \(h\).
\(\tau_i\): Effect of treatment \(i\).
\(\epsilon_{hi} \sim N(0, \sigma^2)\): Random error term.

title: Randomized Complete Block Design (RCBD) with Blocking
text:
Key Assumptions

Normality: The residuals (\(\epsilon_{hi}\)) are normally distributed.
Homogeneity of Variance (Homoscedasticity): The variance of residuals is constant across all treatments and blocks.
Independence: Observations are independent of each other.
No Interaction: There is no interaction between blocks and treatments, i.e., the effect of a treatment is consistent across all blocks.

Deeper Insight: Assumption of no interaction is critical. If this assumption is violated, the RCBD model may not adequately capture the variability, leading to biased estimates of treatment effects. In such cases, more complex designs that account for interactions, like general complete block designs, are necessary.
Reference: Kempthorne (1977) elaborates on the assumptions and their implications in Design and Analysis of Experiments.

title: Randomized Complete Block Design (RCBD) with Blocking
text:
ANOVA for RCBDs
To analyze RCBDs, we employ Analysis of Variance (ANOVA), which decomposes the total variability in the data into components attributable to blocks, treatments, and random error.

Variance Decomposition
\[
\text{Total SS} = \text{Block SS} + \text{Treatment SS} + \text{Error SS}
\]


ANOVA Table










Source of Variation
Degrees of Freedom (DF)
Sum of Squares (SS)
Mean Square (MS)
F-ratio




Blocks
\(b - 1\)
\(SS_\text{Block}\)
\(MS_\text{Block} = SS_\text{Block} / (b-1)\)



Treatments
\(t - 1\)
\(SS_\text{Treatment}\)
\(MS_\text{Treatment} = SS_\text{Treatment} / (t-1)\)
\(\frac{MS_\text{Treatment}}{MS_\text{Error}}\)


Error
\((b-1)(t-1)\)
\(SS_\text{Error}\)
\(MS_\text{Error} = SS_\text{Error} / ((b-1)(t-1))\)



Total
\(bt - 1\)
\(SS_\text{Total}\)






Hypothesis Testing:

Null Hypothesis (\(H_0\)): All treatment means are equal (\(\tau_i = 0\) for all \(i\)).
Alternative Hypothesis (\(H_A\)): At least one treatment mean is different.

Decision Rule: Reject \(H_0\) if the F-ratio exceeds the critical value from the F-distribution with degrees of freedom \((t-1, (b-1)(t-1))\) at the chosen significance level (\(\alpha\)).

Intuitive Explanation: The F-ratio compares the variability due to treatments to the variability due to random error. A higher F-ratio indicates that treatments explain a significant portion of the variability in responses, suggesting that treatment effects are meaningful.

title: Randomized Complete Block Design (RCBD) with Blocking
text:
Example: Bread-Baking Experiment

Scenario
An experimenter aims to compare four bread recipes (treatments) across three oven shelves (blocks). Each shelf is expected to have similar conditions, making it an ideal blocking factor.


Step-by-Step R Code

1. Load Data and Prepare Factors

# Set seed for reproducibility
set.seed(42)

# Define blocks and treatments
blocks <- factor(rep(1:3, each = 4))
treatments <- factor(rep(1:4, times = 3))

# Simulate response variable (e.g., loaf weight in grams)
response <- c(
    rnorm(4, mean = 500, sd = 10), # Block 1
    rnorm(4, mean = 505, sd = 10), # Block 2
    rnorm(4, mean = 498, sd = 10) # Block 3
)

# Create data frame
data <- data.frame(blocks, treatments, response)

# View the data
print(data)

Output Interpretation: The dataset comprises three blocks, each containing all four treatments. The response variable represents the loaf weight, simulated with slight block-specific means to reflect potential block effects.


2. Fit the RCBD Model

# Fit the RCBD model using ANOVA
model <- aov(response ~ blocks + treatments, data = data)

# Summary of the model
summary(model)

Interpretation:

Blocks: Capture the variability due to different oven shelves.
Treatments: Assess the effect of different bread recipes after accounting for block effects.
Error: Represents unexplained variability.



3. Assess Blocking Efficiency
Compare the Mean Square for Blocks (\(MS_\text{Block}\)) with Mean Square for Error (\(MS_\text{Error}\)). A higher \(MS_\text{Block}\) indicates substantial block effects, enhancing the precision of treatment comparisons.


4. Diagnostic Plots

# Diagnostic plots for the ANOVA model
par(mfrow = c(2, 2))
plot(model)
par(mfrow = c(1, 1))

Interpretation:

Residuals vs Fitted: Check for homoscedasticity and non-linearity.
Normal Q-Q: Assess normality of residuals.
Scale-Location: Evaluate homogeneity of variance.
Residuals vs Leverage: Identify influential observations.



5. Multiple Comparisons (Post-Hoc Analysis)

# Load emmeans package for estimated marginal means
library(emmeans)

# Estimated marginal means for treatments
emm <- emmeans(model, ~treatments)

# Pairwise comparisons
pairwise_comparisons <- contrast(emm, method = "pairwise")
summary(pairwise_comparisons)

Interpretation: Identify which bread recipes significantly differ in loaf weight after adjusting for oven shelf effects.

title: Randomized Complete Block Design (RCBD) with Blocking
text:
General Complete Block Designs

Model
For designs where treatments are replicated within blocks, the model extends to include interaction effects:
\[
Y_{hit} = \mu + \theta_h + \tau_i + (\theta \tau)^*_{hi} + \epsilon^*_{hit}
\]
Where:

\(Y_{hit}\): Response for treatment \(i\) in block \(h\), replicate \(t\).
\(\theta_h\): Effect of block \(h\).
\(\tau_i\): Effect of treatment \(i\).
\((\theta \tau)_{hi}\): Interaction effect between block \(h\) and treatment \(i\).
\(\epsilon_{hit}\): Random error.



Sample Size Calculations
Determining the appropriate sample size is crucial for ensuring adequate power in detecting treatment effects.
\[
n \geq \frac{2 v \sigma^2 \phi^2}{b \Delta^2}
\]
Where:

\(n\): Number of replicates per treatment.
\(v\): Number of treatments.
\(\sigma^2\): Variance estimate.
\(\phi\): Desired power.
\(b\): Number of blocks.
\(\Delta\): Minimum detectable effect size.

Deeper Insight: Sample size calculations consider the balance between desired statistical power and the practical constraints of the experiment. Increasing the number of blocks or replicates can enhance the power but may require more resources.

title: Randomized Complete Block Design (RCBD) with Blocking
text:
Handling Block-Treatment Interactions
In scenarios where interaction effects are suspected, it’s essential to include them in the model to avoid biased estimates.

Model with Interaction
\[
Y_{hit} = \mu + \theta_h + \tau_i + (\theta \tau)^*_{hi} + \epsilon^*_{hit}
\]
Implications:

Significant Interaction: Indicates that the effect of treatments varies across blocks, necessitating separate treatment effect analyses within each block.
Non-Significant Interaction: Supports the additive model, validating the use of standard RCBD analysis.

title: Randomized Complete Block Design (RCBD) with Blocking
text:
Example: Resting Metabolic Rate

Scenario
A study aims to compare three different exercise protocols (Treatments A, B, C) on subjects’ resting metabolic rates. The subjects are grouped into four blocks based on age groups to control for age-related variability.


Step-by-Step R Code

1. Load and Prepare Data

# Set seed for reproducibility
set.seed(123)

# Define blocks and treatments
blocks <- factor(rep(1:4, each = 3))
treatments <- factor(rep(c("A", "B", "C"), times = 4))

# Simulate response variable (e.g., resting metabolic rate in kcal/day)
response <- c(
    rnorm(3, mean = 1500, sd = 50), # Block 1
    rnorm(3, mean = 1550, sd = 50), # Block 2
    rnorm(3, mean = 1480, sd = 50), # Block 3
    rnorm(3, mean = 1520, sd = 50) # Block 4
)

# Create data frame
data <- data.frame(blocks, treatments, response)

# View the data
print(data)



2. Fit the RCBD Model

# Fit the RCBD model using ANOVA
model <- aov(response ~ blocks + treatments, data = data)

# Summary of the model
summary(model)

Interpretation:

Blocks: Account for age-related variability.
Treatments: Assess the impact of exercise protocols on metabolic rate after controlling for age.



3. Diagnostic Plots

# Diagnostic plots for the ANOVA model
par(mfrow = c(2, 2))
plot(model)
par(mfrow = c(1, 1))

Interpretation: Ensure that residuals meet ANOVA assumptions. Look for random scatter in Residuals vs Fitted, linearity in Scale-Location, and normality in Q-Q plots.


4. Post-Hoc Analysis

# Load emmeans package for estimated marginal means
library(emmeans)

# Estimated marginal means for treatments
emm <- emmeans(model, ~treatments)

# Pairwise comparisons
pairwise_comparisons <- contrast(emm, method = "pairwise")
summary(pairwise_comparisons)

Interpretation: Determine which exercise protocols significantly differ in their effect on resting metabolic rates after adjusting for age.

title: Randomized Complete Block Design (RCBD) with Blocking
text:
Conclusion
Complete Block Designs (CBDs), particularly Randomized Complete Block Designs (RCBDs), are indispensable in experimental research for controlling variability due to nuisance factors. By structuring experiments to include blocks where each treatment is represented, CBDs enhance the precision and reliability of treatment effect estimates. The integration of ANOVA facilitates robust analysis, allowing researchers to discern meaningful differences among treatments while accounting for block-induced variability.

title: Randomized Complete Block Design (RCBD) with Blocking
text:
Key Takeaways

Blocking: Reduces variability from known sources, increasing the efficiency of treatment comparisons.
ANOVA in RCBDs: Decomposes variability to isolate treatment effects, providing a clear framework for hypothesis testing.
General Complete Block Designs: Extend the utility of CBDs to more complex scenarios involving treatment replications within blocks.
Practical Implementation: R offers comprehensive tools for designing, analyzing, and interpreting CBDs, empowering researchers with robust statistical capabilities.
Advanced Topics: Understanding interactions and sample size considerations enhances the depth and applicability of CBDs in diverse research contexts.

Mastery of Complete Block Designs equips graduate students with the methodological rigor necessary for conducting sophisticated experiments, ensuring that findings are both accurate and generalizable.

title: Randomized Complete Block Design (RCBD) with Blocking
text:
Proof of RCBD Model Assumptions

1. Variance Decomposition
The RCBD model is expressed as:
\[
Y_{hi} = \mu + \theta_h + \tau_i + \epsilon_{hi}
\]
Where:

\(Y_{hi}\): Response for treatment \(i\) in block \(h\).
\(\mu\): Overall mean.
\(\theta_h\): Effect of block \(h\).
\(\tau_i\): Effect of treatment \(i\).
\(\epsilon_{hi} \sim N(0, \sigma^2)\): Error term.



Assumptions

Normality: \(\epsilon_{hi}\) are normally distributed.
Independence: Observations are independent.
Homoscedasticity: \(\sigma^2\) is constant across all treatments and blocks.
No Interaction: Effects of blocks and treatments are additive.



Variance Decomposition
\[
\text{Total SS} = \text{Block SS} + \text{Treatment SS} + \text{Error SS}
\]


Derivation

Total Sum of Squares (SS\(_\text{Total}\)):

\[
SS_\text{Total} = \sum_{h=1}^b \sum_{i=1}^t (Y_{hi} - \bar{Y})^2
\]
Where \(\bar{Y}\) is the grand mean.

Block Sum of Squares (SS\(_\text{Block}\)):

\[
SS_\text{Block} = t \sum_{h=1}^b (\bar{Y}_h - \bar{Y})^2
\]
Where \(\bar{Y}_h\) is the mean of block \(h\).

Treatment Sum of Squares (SS\(_\text{Treatment}\)):

\[
SS_\text{Treatment} = b \sum_{i=1}^t (\bar{Y}_i - \bar{Y})^2
\]
Where \(\bar{Y}_i\) is the mean of treatment \(i\).

Error Sum of Squares (SS\(_\text{Error}\)):

\[
SS_\text{Error} = \sum_{h=1}^b \sum_{i=1}^t (Y_{hi} - \bar{Y}_h - \bar{Y}_i + \bar{Y})^2
\]
Represents variability not explained by blocks or treatments.
Conclusion: The variance decomposition allows for the assessment of how much variability in the response is attributable to blocks, treatments, and random error.

title: Randomized Complete Block Design (RCBD) with Blocking
text:
Effects of Ignoring Block-Treatment Interaction
In the RCBD model, it is assumed that there is no interaction between blocks and treatments. Ignoring a significant block-treatment interaction can lead to biased estimates of treatment effects.

Mathematical Illustration
Suppose the true model includes an interaction term:
\[
Y_{hi} = \mu + \theta_h + \tau_i + (\theta \tau)^*_{hi} + \epsilon^*_{hi}
\]
If the interaction term \((\theta \tau)_{hi}\) is significant and is omitted from the model, the estimates of \(\tau_i\) will be biased because the model incorrectly attributes part of the interaction effect to treatment effects.


Proof Outline

Full Model: Includes interaction.
Reduced Model: Omits interaction.
Bias Derivation: Show that \(\hat{\tau}_i\) in the reduced model includes components of the interaction effect.

Conclusion: It is crucial to test for block-treatment interactions. If significant, a more complex model that includes interaction terms should be employed.

title: Randomized Complete Block Design (RCBD) with Blocking
text:
Sample Size Calculations for RCBDs
Determining the appropriate sample size is essential for achieving sufficient power to detect treatment effects.

Formula
\[
n \geq \frac{2 v \sigma^2 \phi^2}{b \Delta^2}
\]
Where:

\(n\): Number of replicates per treatment.
\(v\): Number of treatments.
\(\sigma^2\): Estimated variance of the response.
\(\phi\): Desired power (e.g., 0.80).
\(b\): Number of blocks.
\(\Delta\): Minimum detectable effect size.



Derivation

Power Analysis: Based on the desired power (\(\phi\)) and significance level (\(\alpha\)), determine the non-centrality parameter needed to detect effect size \(\Delta\).
Rearrange for \(n\): Solving the power equation for \(n\) yields the sample size formula.

Example Calculation: Suppose you have 4 treatments (\(v = 4\)), 5 blocks (\(b = 5\)), an estimated variance (\(\sigma^2 = 20\)), desire a power of 0.80 (\(\phi = 0.84\)), and aim to detect a minimum effect size of 5 units (\(\Delta = 5\)).
\[
n \geq \frac{2 \times 4 \times 20 \times 0.84^2}{5 \times 5^2} = \frac{2 \times 4 \times 20 \times 0.7056}{125} \approx \frac{113.792}{125} \approx 0.91
\]
Since \(n\) must be an integer, at least 1 replicate per treatment is needed. However, practical considerations often necessitate larger sample sizes.

title: Randomized Complete Block Design (RCBD) with Blocking
text:
Medium Difficulty

Two-Way ANCOVA with Interaction:

Dataset: Simulate a dataset with three treatments and one covariate.
Tasks:

Generate data for treatments A, B, C with a covariate X.
Fit an ANCOVA model adjusting for X.
Test the significance of treatment effects and the covariate.
Generate diagnostic plots and interpret them.



R Code Example:

set.seed(123)

# Define factors and covariate
Treatment <- factor(rep(c("A", "B", "C"), each = 30))
X <- rnorm(90, mean = 50, sd = 10)

# Simulate responses with treatment effects and covariate effect
Y <- 5 + ifelse(Treatment == "A", 0, ifelse(Treatment == "B", 2, 4)) +
    0.5 * (X - mean(X)) + rnorm(90, mean = 0, sd = 3)

data_sim <- data.frame(Treatment, X, Y)

# Fit ANCOVA model
model_sim <- lm(Y ~ Treatment + X, data = data_sim)
summary(model_sim)

# Diagnostic plots
par(mfrow = c(2, 2))
plot(model_sim)

# Estimated marginal means
library(emmeans)
emm_sim <- emmeans(model_sim, ~Treatment)
pairwise_sim <- contrast(emm_sim, method = "pairwise")
summary(pairwise_sim)

Questions:

What are the main effects of Treatment and the covariate X?
Are there significant differences between treatments after adjusting for X?
Do the diagnostic plots suggest any assumption violations?


Balloon Data Analysis:

Scenario: Reanalyze the balloon data, testing for equality of slopes.
Tasks:

Fit an ANCOVA model.
Test the homogeneity of regression slopes.
Interpret the adjusted treatment means.



R Code Example:

library(car)
library(emmeans)

# Load and prepare data
balloon.data <- read.table("data/dean2017/balloon.txt", header = TRUE)

balloon.data |> dplyr::glimpse()

balloon.data <- within(balloon.data, {
    x <- Order - mean(Order)
    fColor <- factor(Color)
})

# Fit ANCOVA model
model <- lm(Time ~ fColor + x, data = balloon.data)
summary(model)

# Test homogeneity of slopes
model_interaction <- lm(Time ~ fColor * x, data = balloon.data)
anova(model, model_interaction)

# Estimated marginal means
emm_balloon <- emmeans(model, ~fColor)
pairwise_balloon <- contrast(emm_balloon, method = "pairwise")
summary(pairwise_balloon)

Questions:

Does the interaction term indicate equality of slopes across treatments?
How do the adjusted means compare across balloon colors?
What conclusions can be drawn about the effect of balloon color on inflation time after adjusting for run order?

title: Randomized Complete Block Design (RCBD) with Blocking
text:
Challenging Problems

Unbalanced Two-Factor ANCOVA Analysis:

Dataset: Utilize a dataset with unequal numbers of replicates across treatment combinations.
Tasks:

Simulate an unbalanced dataset with two factors and one covariate.
Fit an ANCOVA model using both Type II and Type III sums of squares.
Compare the results and discuss how imbalance affects the interpretation of main and interaction effects.



R Code Example:

library(car)

set.seed(456)

# Simulate unbalanced data
FactorA <- factor(rep(c("A1", "A2", "A3"), times = c(4, 6, 5)))
FactorB <- factor(rep(c("B1", "B2"), each = 7, times = 2))
X <- rnorm(15, mean = 50, sd = 10)

# Simulate responses with treatment and covariate effects
Y <- 5 + ifelse(FactorA == "A1", 0, ifelse(FactorA == "A2", 2, 4)) + ifelse(FactorB == "B1", 0, 3) + 0.5 * (X - mean(X)) + rnorm(15, mean = 0, sd = 3)

data_unbalanced <- data.frame(FactorA, FactorB, X, Y)

# Fit ANCOVA model
fit_unbalanced <- lm(Y ~ FactorA * FactorB + X, data = data_unbalanced)

# Type II Sum of Squares
typeII <- car::Anova(fit_unbalanced, type = "II")
print(typeII)

# Type III Sum of Squares
typeIII <- car::Anova(fit_unbalanced, type = "III")
print(typeIII)

title: Randomized Complete Block Design (RCBD) with Blocking
text:
Discussion Points

Type II vs. Type III SS:

Type II: Tests main effects after accounting for other main effects but ignores interactions.
Type III: Tests main effects after accounting for all other factors, including interactions.

Impact of Imbalance:

Imbalanced designs can lead to different interpretations under Type II and Type III SS.
Type I SS is not appropriate here as it is sequential and depends on the order of factors.

Significance of Effects:

Identify which factors and interactions are significant under each type.
Discuss how imbalance might inflate or deflate the significance levels of certain effects.

Implications for Experimental Conclusions:

Choosing the appropriate type of sums of squares is crucial for accurate inference.
Misinterpretation can lead to incorrect conclusions about factor effects and interactions.



Three-Factor Interaction Interpretation:

Dataset: Use a simulated dataset with three factors exhibiting a significant three-way interaction.
Tasks:

Simulate data with three factors and one covariate.
Fit a three-way ANCOVA model.
Visualize the three-way interaction.
Use emmeans to estimate marginal means and perform pairwise comparisons.
Explain how the three-way interaction affects the interpretation of main and two-way interactions.

title: Randomized Complete Block Design (RCBD) with Blocking
text:
R Code Example

library(emmeans)
library(ggplot2)

set.seed(789)

# Simulate data
FactorA <- factor(rep(c("A1", "A2", "A3"), each = 24))
FactorB <- factor(rep(c("B1", "B2"), each = 12, times = 3))
FactorC <- factor(rep(c("C1", "C2", "C3"), times = 8))
X <- rnorm(72, mean = 50, sd = 10)

# Simulate responses with three-way interaction
Y <- 5 + ifelse(FactorA == "A1", 0, ifelse(FactorA == "A2", 2, 4)) + ifelse(FactorB == "B1", 0, 3) + ifelse(FactorC == "C1", 0, ifelse(FactorC == "C2", 1.5, 3)) + 0.5 * (X - mean(X)) + ifelse(FactorA == "A1" & FactorB == "B1", 0, ifelse(FactorA == "A2" & FactorB == "B2", 1, 2) + rnorm(72, mean = 0, sd = 3)

data_three <- data.frame(FactorA, FactorB, FactorC, X, Y)

# Fit three-way ANCOVA model
fit_three <- lm(Y ~ FactorA * FactorB * FactorC + X, data = data_three)
summary(fit_three)

# Plot three-way interaction
ggplot(data_three, aes(x = FactorA, y = Y, color = FactorB, group = FactorB)) +
    geom_point() +
    geom_line() +
    facet_wrap(~FactorC) +
    labs(title = "Three-Way Interaction Plot", x = "Factor A", y = "Response") +
    theme_minimal()

# Estimated marginal means
emm_three <- emmeans(fit_three, ~ FactorA * FactorB * FactorC)
contrast_results <- contrast(emm_three, method = "pairwise", adjust = "none")
summary(contrast_results)

title: Randomized Complete Block Design (RCBD) with Blocking
text:
Interpretation

Three-Way Interaction: The interaction plot shows how the interaction between Factor A and Factor B varies across levels of Factor C. Non-parallel lines across different facets (Factor C levels) indicate a significant three-way interaction.
Impact on Main and Two-Way Interactions: Significant higher-order interactions imply that main effects and two-way interactions cannot be interpreted in isolation. The effect of one factor depends on the combination of other factors.
Practical Implications: Understanding three-way interactions allows for more nuanced insights into how multiple factors jointly influence the response variable, leading to better-informed decisions and strategies.

Reference: Dean, Voss & Draguljić (2017) elaborate on interpreting higher-order interactions in Design and Analysis of Experiments.

Mathematical Proof of Interaction Contrasts:

Task: Derive formulas for interaction contrasts in a three-factor design and prove that they measure deviations from additivity.
Requirements:

Show how to construct interaction contrasts.
Prove that if all interaction contrasts are zero, the model is additive.



Hints:

Utilize the definitions of main effects and interaction terms.
Employ properties of linear algebra to demonstrate the relationship between interaction contrasts and additivity.
Reference Dean et al. (2017) and Christensen (2018) for theoretical foundations.

title: Randomized Complete Block Design (RCBD) with Blocking
text:
Proof Outline

Define the Three-Factor Model:

\[
Y_{ijk} = \mu + \alpha_i + \beta_j + \gamma_k + (\alpha\beta)^*_{ij} + (\alpha\gamma)^*_{ik} + (\beta\gamma)^*_{jk} + (\alpha\beta\gamma)^*_{ijk} + \epsilon_{ijk}
\]
where \(\sum \alpha_i = \sum \beta_j = \sum \gamma_k = 0\).

Construct Interaction Contrasts:


Two-Way Interactions:

\((\alpha\beta)^*_{ij}\) measures the interaction between Factors A and B.
Similarly for \((\alpha\gamma)^*_{ik}\) and \((\beta\gamma)^*_{jk}\).

Three-Way Interaction:

\((\alpha\beta\gamma)_{ijk}\) measures the deviation from additivity among all three factors.



Proof of Additivity:

Additive Model: If all interaction terms are zero (\((\alpha\beta)^*_{ij} = (\alpha\gamma)^*_{ik} = (\beta\gamma)^*{jk} = (\alpha\beta\gamma)^*_{ijk} = 0\)), the model simplifies to:


\[
Y_{ijk} = \mu + \alpha_i + \beta_j + \gamma_k + \epsilon_{ijk}
\]
indicating that the response is purely additive with respect to the main effects.

Zero Interaction Contrasts:
If all interaction contrasts are zero, the model exhibits additivity. Thus, interaction contrasts quantify how much the actual model deviates from an additive one.


Conclusion:

Interaction contrasts provide a mathematical measure of the presence and magnitude of interactions. Non-zero contrasts indicate that the combined effect of factors is not merely the sum of their individual effects, highlighting the importance of considering interactions in experimental analysis.
Reference: Dean, Voss & Draguljić (2017) offer detailed mathematical treatments of interaction contrasts in Design and Analysis of Experiments.

title: Randomized Complete Block Design (RCBD) with Blocking
text:
Proof of RCBD Model Assumptions

1. Variance Decomposition
The RCBD model is expressed as:
\[
Y_{hi} = \mu + \theta_h + \tau_i + \epsilon_{hi}
\]
Where:

\(Y_{hi}\): Response for treatment \(i\) in block \(h\).
\(\mu\): Overall mean.
\(\theta_h\): Effect of block \(h\).
\(\tau_i\): Effect of treatment \(i\).
\(\epsilon_{hi} \sim N(0, \sigma^2)\): Error term.

Assumptions: 1. Normality: \(\epsilon_{hi}\) are normally distributed. 2. Independence: Observations are independent. 3. Homoscedasticity: \(\sigma^2\) is constant across all treatments and blocks. 4. No Interaction: Effects of blocks and treatments are additive.
Variance Decomposition:
\[
\text{Total SS} = \text{Block SS} + \text{Treatment SS} + \text{Error SS}
\]
Derivation: 1. Total Sum of Squares (SS\(_\text{Total}\)):
\[
SS_\text{Total} = \sum_{h=1}^b \sum_{i=1}^t (Y_{hi} - \bar{Y})^2
\]
Where \(\bar{Y}\) is the grand mean.

Block Sum of Squares (SS\(_\text{Block}\)):

\[
SS_\text{Block} = t \sum_{h=1}^b (\bar{Y}_h - \bar{Y})^2
\]
Where \(\bar{Y}_h\) is the mean of block \(h\).

Treatment Sum of Squares (SS\(_\text{Treatment}\)):

\[
SS_\text{Treatment} = b \sum_{i=1}^t (\bar{Y}_i - \bar{Y})^2
\]
Where \(\bar{Y}_i\) is the mean of treatment \(i\).

Error Sum of Squares (SS\(_\text{Error}\)):

\[
SS_\text{Error} = \sum_{h=1}^b \sum_{i=1}^t (Y_{hi} - \bar{Y}_h - \bar{Y}_i + \bar{Y})^2
\]
Represents variability not explained by blocks or treatments.
Conclusion: The variance decomposition allows for the assessment of how much variability in the response is attributable to blocks, treatments, and random error.
Reference: Montgomery (2019) provides a detailed derivation of ANOVA components in Design and Analysis of Experiments.


2. Effects of Ignoring Block-Treatment Interaction
In the RCBD model, it is assumed that there is no interaction between blocks and treatments. Ignoring a significant block-treatment interaction can lead to biased estimates of treatment effects.
Mathematical Illustration:
Suppose the true model includes an interaction term:
\[
Y_{hi} = \mu + \theta_h + \tau_i + (\theta \tau)^*_{hi} + \epsilon^*_{hi}
\]
If the interaction term \((\theta \tau)_{hi}\) is significant and is omitted from the model, the estimates of \(\tau_i\) will be biased because the model incorrectly attributes part of the interaction effect to treatment effects.
Proof Outline: 1. Full Model: Includes interaction. 2. Reduced Model: Omits interaction. 3. Bias Derivation: Show that \(\hat{\tau}_i\) in the reduced model includes components of the interaction effect.
Conclusion: It is crucial to test for block-treatment interactions. If significant, a more complex model that includes interaction terms should be employed.
Reference: Kempthorne (1977) discusses the implications of model misspecification in Design and Analysis of Experiments.

title: Randomized Complete Block Design (RCBD) with Blocking
text:
Sample Size Calculations for RCBDs
Determining the appropriate sample size is essential for ensuring adequate power to detect treatment effects.

Formula
\[
n \geq \frac{2 v \sigma^2 \phi^2}{b \Delta^2}
\]
Where:

\(n\): Number of replicates per treatment.
\(v\): Number of treatments.
\(\sigma^2\): Variance estimate.
\(\phi\): Desired power (e.g., 0.80).
\(b\): Number of blocks.
\(\Delta\): Minimum detectable effect size.



Derivation

Power Analysis: Based on the desired power (\(\phi\)) and significance level (\(\alpha\)), determine the non-centrality parameter needed to detect effect size \(\Delta\).
Rearrange for \(n\): Solving the power equation for \(n\) yields the sample size formula.

Example Calculation:
Suppose you have 4 treatments (\(v = 4\)), 5 blocks (\(b = 5\)), an estimated variance (\(\sigma^2 = 20\)), desire a power of 0.80 (\(\phi = 0.84\)), and aim to detect a minimum effect size of 5 units (\(\Delta = 5\)).
\[
n \geq \frac{2 \times 4 \times 20 \times 0.84^2}{5 \times 5^2} = \frac{2 \times 4 \times 20 \times 0.7056}{125} \approx \frac{113.792}{125} \approx 0.91
\]
Since \(n\) must be an integer, at least 1 replicate per treatment is needed. However, practical considerations often necessitate larger sample sizes.
Reference: Montgomery (2019) elaborates on sample size determination in Design and Analysis of Experiments.

title: Randomized Complete Block Design (RCBD) with Blocking
text:
Handling Block-Treatment Interactions
In scenarios where interaction effects between blocks and treatments are suspected, it is essential to include them in the model to avoid biased estimates and incorrect inferences.

Model with Interaction
\[
Y_{hi} = \mu + \theta_h + \tau_i + (\theta \tau)^*_{hi} + \epsilon^*_{hi}
\]
Implications:

Significant Interaction: Suggests that the effect of treatments varies across blocks. Separate treatment effect analyses within each block may be necessary.
Non-Significant Interaction: Supports the additive model, validating the use of standard RCBD analysis.

Reference: Kempthorne (1977) elaborates on the importance of accounting for interactions in Design and Analysis of Experiments.

title: Randomized Complete Block Design (RCBD) with Blocking
section: Sample Size Calculation Example in R
text:
Sample Size Calculation Example in R
To determine the necessary number of replicates per treatment in an RCBD, you can use R for power and sample size calculations.

# Parameters
v <- 4 # Number of treatments
b <- 5 # Number of blocks
sigma2 <- 20 # Variance estimate
phi <- 0.84 # Desired power (approx 0.80)
Delta <- 5 # Minimum detectable effect size

# Calculate sample size
n <- ceiling((2 * v * sigma2 * phi^2) / (b * Delta^2))
print(n)

Interpretation: The ceiling function ensures that the sample size is rounded up to the next integer, ensuring adequate power.

title: Randomized Complete Block Design (RCBD) with Blocking
text:
Medium Difficulty

Two-Way ANCOVA with Interaction:

Dataset: Simulate a dataset with three treatments and one covariate.
Tasks:

Generate data for treatments A, B, C with a covariate X.
Fit an ANCOVA model adjusting for X.
Test the significance of treatment effects and the covariate.
Generate diagnostic plots and interpret them.



R Code Example:

set.seed(123)

# Define factors and covariate
Treatment <- factor(rep(c("A", "B", "C"), each=30))
X <- rnorm(90, mean=50,   sd=10)

# Simulate responses with treatment effects and covariate effect
Y <- ifelse(Treatment == "A", 0, ifelse(Treatment == "B", 2, 4) + 0.5 * (X - mean(X)) + rnorm(90, mean=0, sd=3)

data_sim <- data.frame(Treatment, X, Y)

# Fit ANCOVA model
model_sim <- lm(Y ~ Treatment + X, data = data_sim)
summary(model_sim)

# Diagnostic plots
par(mfrow = c(2, 2))
plot(model_sim)

# Estimated marginal means
library(emmeans)
emm_sim <- emmeans(model_sim ~ Treatment)
pairwise_sim <- contrast(emm_sim, method = "pairwise")
summary(pairwise_sim)

Questions: - What are the main effects of Treatment and the covariate X? - Are there significant differences between treatments after adjusting for X? - Do the diagnostic plots suggest any assumption violations?

Balloon Data Analysis:

Scenario: Reanalyze the balloon data, testing for equality of slopes.
Tasks:

Fit an ANCOVA model.
Test the homogeneity of regression slopes.
Interpret the adjusted treatment means.




R Code Example

library(car)
library(emmeans)

# Load and prepare data
balloon.data <- read.table("data/balloon.txt", header = TRUE)
balloon.data <- within(balloon.data
, x <- Order - mean(Order)
fColor <- factor(Color)
})

# Fit ANCOVA model
model <- lm(Time ~ fColor + x, data = balloon.data)
summary(model)

# Test homogeneity of slopes
model_interaction <- lm(Time ~ fColor * x, data = balloon.data)
anova(model, model_interaction)

# Estimated marginal means
emm_balloon <- emmeans(model ~ fColor)
pairwise_balloon <- contrast(emm_balloon, method = "pairwise")
summary(pairwise_balloon)

Questions:

Does the interaction term indicate equality of slopes across treatments?
How do the adjusted means compare across balloon colors?
What conclusions can be drawn about the effect of balloon color on inflation time after adjusting for run order?

title: Randomized Complete Block Design (RCBD) with Blocking
text:
Challenging Problems

Unbalanced Two-Factor ANCOVA Analysis:

Dataset: Utilize a dataset with unequal numbers of replicates across treatment combinations.
Tasks:

Simulate an unbalanced dataset with two factors and one covariate.
Fit an ANCOVA model using both Type II and Type III sums of squares.
Compare the results and discuss how imbalance affects the interpretation of main and interaction effects.




R Code Example

library(car)

set.seed(456)

# Simulate unbalanced data
FactorA <- factor(rep(c("A1", "A2", "A3"), times = c(4, 6, 5)))
FactorB <- factor(rep(c("B1", "B2"), each = 7, times = 2))
X <- rnorm(15, mean = 50, sd = 10)

# Simulate responses with treatment and covariate effects
Y <- 5 + ifelse(FactorA == "A1", 0, ifelse(FactorA == "A2", 2, 4)) + ifelse(FactorB == "B1", 0, 3) + 0.5 * (X - mean(X)) + rnorm(15, mean = 0, sd = 3)

data_unbalanced <- data.frame(FactorA, FactorB, X, Y)

# Fit ANCOVA model
fit_unbalanced <- lm(Y ~ FactorA * FactorB + X, data = data_unbalanced)

# Type II Sum of Squares
typeII <- Anova(fit_unbalanced, type = "II")
print(typeII)

# Type III Sum of Squares
typeIII <- Anova(fit_unbalanced, type = "III")
print(typeIII)

title: Randomized Complete Block Design (RCBD) with Blocking
text:
Discussion Points:

Type II vs. Type III SS:

Type II: Tests main effects after accounting for other main effects but ignores interactions.
Type III: Tests main effects after accounting for all other factors, including interactions.

Impact of Imbalance:

Imbalanced designs can lead to different interpretations under Type II and Type III SS.
Type I SS is not appropriate here as it is sequential and depends on the order of factors.

Significance of Effects:

Identify which factors and interactions are significant under each type.
Discuss how imbalance might inflate or deflate the significance levels of certain effects.

Implications for Experimental Conclusions:

Choosing the appropriate type of sums of squares is crucial for accurate inference.
Misinterpretation can lead to incorrect conclusions about factor effects and interactions.


Reference: Christensen (2018) provides guidance on handling unbalanced designs and selecting appropriate sums of squares types in Analysis of Variance, Design, and Regression.

Three-Factor Interaction Interpretation:

Dataset: Use a simulated dataset with three factors exhibiting a significant three-way interaction.
Tasks:

Simulate data with three factors and one covariate.
Fit a three-way ANCOVA model.
Visualize the three-way interaction.
Use emmeans to estimate marginal means and perform pairwise comparisons.
Explain how the three-way interaction affects the interpretation of main and two-way interactions.




R Code Example:

library(emmeans)
library(ggplot2)

set.seed(789)

# Simulate data
FactorA <- factor(rep(c("A1", "A2", "A3"), each = 24))
FactorB <- factor(rep(c("B1", "B2"), each = 12, times = 3))
FactorC <- factor(rep(c("C1", "C2", "C3"), times = 8))
X <- rnorm(72, mean = 50, sd = 10)

# Simulate responses with three-way interaction
Y <- 5 +
    ifelse(FactorA == "A1", 0, ifelse(FactorA == "A2", 2, 4)) +
    ifelse(FactorB == "B1", 0, 3) +
    ifelse(FactorC == "C1", 0, ifelse(FactorC == "C2", 1.5, 3)) +
    0.5 * (X - mean(X)) +
    ifelse(FactorA == "A1" & FactorB == "B1", 0,
        ifelse(FactorA == "A2" & FactorB == "B2", 1, 2)
    ) +
    rnorm(72, mean = 0, sd = 3)

data_three <- data.frame(FactorA, FactorB, FactorC, X, Y)

# Fit three-way ANCOVA model
fit_three <- lm(Y ~ FactorA * FactorB * FactorC + X, data = data_three)
summary(fit_three)

# Plot three-way interaction
ggplot(data_three, aes(x = FactorA, y = Y, color = FactorB, group = FactorB)) +
    geom_point() +
    geom_line() +
    facet_wrap(~FactorC) +
    labs(title = "Three-Way Interaction Plot", x = "Factor A", y = "Response") +
    theme_minimal()

# Estimated marginal means
emm_three <- emmeans(fit_three, ~ FactorA * FactorB * FactorC)
contrast_results <- contrast(emm_three, method = "pairwise", adjust = "none")
summary(contrast_results)

title: Randomized Complete Block Design (RCBD) with Blocking
text:
Interpretation

Three-Way Interaction: The interaction plot illustrates how the interaction between Factor A and Factor B varies across different levels of Factor C. Non-parallel lines across facets indicate a significant three-way interaction.
Impact on Main and Two-Way Interactions: Significant higher-order interactions imply that main effects and two-way interactions cannot be interpreted in isolation. The effect of one factor depends on the combination of other factors.
Practical Implications: Understanding three-way interactions allows for more nuanced insights into how multiple factors jointly influence the response variable, leading to better-informed decisions and strategies.

Reference: Dean, Voss & Draguljić (2017) elaborate on interpreting higher-order interactions in Design and Analysis of Experiments.

Mathematical Proof of Interaction Contrasts:

Task: Derive formulas for interaction contrasts in a three-factor design and prove that they measure deviations from additivity.
Requirements:

Show how to construct interaction contrasts.
Prove that if all interaction contrasts are zero, the model is additive.


Hints:

Utilize the definitions of main effects and interaction terms.
Employ properties of linear algebra to demonstrate the relationship between interaction contrasts and additivity.
Reference Dean et al. (2017) and Christensen (2018) for theoretical foundations.

title: Randomized Complete Block Design (RCBD) with Blocking
text:
Proof Outline:

Define the Three-Factor Model:

\[
Y_{ijk} = \mu + \alpha_i + \beta_j + \gamma_k + (\alpha\beta)^*_{ij} + (\alpha\gamma)^*{ik} + (\beta\gamma)^*_{jk} + (\alpha\beta\gamma)^*_{ijk} + \epsilon_{ijk}
\]
where \(\sum \alpha_i = \sum \beta_j = \sum \gamma_k = 0\).

Construct Interaction Contrasts:


Two-Way Interactions:
\((\alpha\beta)_{ij}\) measures the interaction between Factors A and B.
Similarly for \((\alpha\gamma)^*_{ik}\) and \((\beta\gamma)^*_{jk}\).
Three-Way Interaction:
\((\alpha\beta\gamma)_{ijk}\) measures the deviation from additivity among all three factors.


Proof of Additivity:


Additive Model: If all interaction terms are zero (\((\alpha\beta)^*_{ij} = (\alpha\gamma)^*_{ik} = (\beta\gamma)^*_{jk} = (\alpha\beta\gamma)^*_{ijk} = 0\)), the model simplifies to:

\[
Y_{ijk} = \mu + \alpha_i + \beta_j + \gamma_k + \epsilon_{ijk}
\]
indicating that the response is purely additive with respect to the main effects.

Zero Interaction Contrasts:
If all interaction contrasts are zero, the model exhibits additivity. Thus, interaction contrasts quantify how much the actual model deviates from an additive one.


Conclusion:

Interaction contrasts provide a mathematical measure of the presence and magnitude of interactions. Non-zero contrasts indicate that the combined effect of factors is not merely the sum of their individual effects, highlighting the importance of considering interactions in experimental analysis.
Reference: Dean, Voss & Draguljić (2017) offer detailed mathematical treatments of interaction contrasts in Design and Analysis of Experiments.

title: Randomized Complete Block Design (RCBD) with Blocking
text:
Adjusted Treatment Means
The adjusted mean for treatment \(i\) accounts for the influence of the covariate, providing a more accurate estimate of the treatment effect.
\[
\mu + \tau_i = \bar{Y}_i - \beta (\bar{X}_i - \bar{X})
\]
Where:

\(\mu\): Overall mean.
\(\tau_i\): Treatment effect for treatment \(i\).
\(\bar{Y}_i\): Mean response for treatment \(i\).
\(\beta\): Regression coefficient for the covariate.
\(\bar{X}_i\): Mean covariate value for treatment \(i\).
\(\bar{X}\): Overall mean of the covariate.

title: Randomized Complete Block Design (RCBD) with Blocking
text:
Derivation

Model Equation:

\[
Y_{ij} = \mu + \tau_i + \beta (X_{ij} - \bar{X}) + \epsilon_{ij}
\]

Taking the Mean for Treatment \(i\):

\[
\bar{Y}_i = \mu + \tau_i + \beta (\bar{X}_i - \bar{X}) + \bar{\epsilon}_i
\]
Since \(\bar{\epsilon}_i = 0\) (assuming errors have mean zero),
\[
\bar{Y}_i = \mu + \tau_i + \beta (\bar{X}_i - \bar{X})
\]

Solving for Adjusted Mean:

\[
\mu + \tau_i = \bar{Y}_i - \beta (\bar{X}_i - \bar{X})
\]
This equation represents the adjusted treatment mean, accounting for differences in the covariate.
Reference: Montgomery (2019) and Scheffé (1959) provide detailed derivations of adjusted means in ANCOVA.

F-Test for Homogeneity of Slopes
Testing the assumption of homogeneity of regression slopes ensures that the relationship between the covariate and the response is consistent across all treatment groups.


Model Comparison

Model Without Interaction (Assuming Homogeneous Slopes): \[
Y_{hi} = \mu + \theta_h + \tau_i + \beta X_{hi} + \epsilon_{hi}
\]

Where \(\beta\) is the common slope for all treatments.

Model With Interaction (Allowing Slopes to Vary): \[
Y_{hi} = \mu + \theta_h + \tau_i + \beta X_{hi} + (\theta \tau)^*_{hi} + \epsilon^*_{hi}
\]

Where \((\theta \tau)_{hi}\) allows the slope of the covariate to vary with treatments.


Hypothesis Testing

Null Hypothesis (\(H_0\)): Homogeneity of slopes (\(\beta\) is the same across treatments).
Alternative Hypothesis (\(H_A\)): Slopes vary across treatments (\(\beta_i \neq \beta_j\) for some \(i, j\)).



Test Statistic
\[
F = \frac{\text{SSR}^*_{\text{Interaction}} / \text{DF}^*_{\text{Interaction}}}{\text{SSE} / \text{DF}_{\text{Error}}}
\]
Where:

\(\text{SSR}_{\text{Interaction}}\): Sum of squares for the interaction term.
\(\text{DF}_{\text{Interaction}}\): Degrees of freedom for the interaction.
\(\text{SSE}\): Sum of squares for error.
\(\text{DF}_{\text{Error}}\): Degrees of freedom for error.

Decision Rule: Reject \(H_0\) if \(F\) exceeds the critical value from the F-distribution with degrees of freedom \((\text{DF}*{\text{Interaction}}, \text{DF}*{\text{Error}})\).
Conclusion: A significant \(F\)-statistic indicates that the slopes are not homogeneous, violating a key ANCOVA assumption.
Reference: Scheffé (1959) elaborates on hypothesis testing for interaction terms in ANCOVA.

title: Randomized Complete Block Design (RCBD) with Blocking
text:
Confidence Intervals for Higher-Order Contrasts
For higher-order interactions involving multiple factors, confidence intervals for contrasts provide insights into the magnitude and significance of these interactions.

Formula
\[
\text{CI} = \hat{L} \pm t_{\alpha/2, df} \sqrt{\text{Var}(\hat{L})}
\]
Where:

\(\hat{L}\): Estimated contrast.
\(t_{\alpha/2, df}\): Critical value from the t-distribution.
\(\text{Var}(\hat{L})\): Variance of the contrast estimate.



Steps in R

Estimate the Contrast: Using the emmeans package to define and estimate contrasts.
Calculate the Confidence Interval: The emmeans package automatically provides confidence intervals when performing contrasts.



Example:

library(emmeans)

# Fit the ANCOVA model
model <- lm(Y ~ Treatment + X, data = data_sim)

# Define estimated marginal means
emm <- emmeans(model, ~Treatment)

# Define a contrast (e.g., Treatment B vs. Treatment A)
contrast_AB <- contrast(emm, method = "pairwise")
summary(contrast_AB, infer = TRUE)



Interpretation:
The output provides the estimated difference, standard error, t-value, and confidence interval for the contrast. If the confidence interval does not include zero, the contrast is statistically significant.
Reference: Christensen (2018) discusses confidence intervals for contrasts in Analysis of Variance, Design, and Regression.

title: Randomized Complete Block Design (RCBD) with Blocking
text:
Conclusion
Complete Block Designs (CBDs), particularly Randomized Complete Block Designs (RCBDs), are invaluable in experimental research for controlling variability due to nuisance factors. By structuring experiments to include blocks where each treatment is represented, CBDs enhance the precision and reliability of treatment effect estimates. The integration of ANOVA facilitates robust analysis, allowing researchers to discern meaningful differences among treatments while accounting for block-induced variability.

title: Randomized Complete Block Design (RCBD) with Blocking
text:
Key Takeaways

Blocking: Reduces variability from known sources, increasing the efficiency of treatment comparisons.
ANOVA in RCBDs: Decomposes variability to isolate treatment effects, providing a clear framework for hypothesis testing.
General Complete Block Designs: Extend the utility of CBDs to more complex scenarios involving treatment replications within blocks.
Practical Implementation: R offers comprehensive tools for designing, analyzing, and interpreting CBDs, empowering researchers with robust statistical capabilities.
Advanced Topics: Understanding interactions and sample size considerations enhances the depth and applicability of CBDs in diverse research contexts.

title: Randomized Complete Block Design (RCBD) with Blocking
text:
References

Dean, A., Voss, D., & Draguljić, D. (2017). Design and Analysis of Experiments. Springer.
Montgomery, D. C., & Runger, G. C. (2010). Applied Statistics and Probability for Engineers. Wiley.
Christensen, R. (2018). Analysis of Variance, Design, and Regression. Chapman and Hall/CRC.
Kempthorne, O. (1977). Design and Analysis of Experiments. Robert E. Krieger Publishing Company.
Scheffé, H. (1959). The Analysis of Variance. Wiley.

title: Comparisons and Contrasts
text:
In many experiments, researchers compare multiple treatments or conditions to understand their effects on a response variable. For example, consider a horticulturalist testing various fertilizers on plant growth or a biologist examining different drugs on patient outcomes. After performing an ANOVA and finding evidence that not all treatment means are equal, the next step is to determine which treatments differ, and by how much.
Multiple Comparison Procedures (MCPs) and contrasts address this challenge:

MCPs control the overall probability of false positives (Type I errors) when making many comparisons.
Contrasts focus on specific, pre-defined linear combinations of treatment means, often reflecting scientific questions.

The combination of MCPs and contrasts ensures valid inferences, mitigating the risk of drawing erroneous conclusions from multiple tests while retaining interpretability and power.



Understand the rationale for performing multiple comparisons after ANOVA.
Explore common MCPs: Fisher’s LSD, Tukey’s HSD, Bonferroni, and Scheffé methods.
Learn how to construct orthogonal and non-orthogonal contrasts and interpret their results.
Utilize R to perform multiple comparisons and test contrasts on real or simulated data.
Discuss Type I error control, power considerations, and the trade-offs in choosing different procedures.
Develop deeper theoretical insights (in the Appendix) and practice through exercises of medium and challenging difficulty.

title: Comparisons and Contrasts
text:
Understand the rationale for performing multiple comparisons after ANOVA.
Explore common MCPs: Fisher’s LSD, Tukey’s HSD, Bonferroni, and Scheffé methods.
Learn how to construct orthogonal and non-orthogonal contrasts and interpret their results.
Utilize R to perform multiple comparisons and test contrasts on real or simulated data.
Discuss Type I error control, power considerations, and the trade-offs in choosing different procedures.
Develop deeper theoretical insights (in the Appendix) and practice through exercises of medium and challenging difficulty.

title: Comparisons and Contrasts
text:
What is a Contrast?
A contrast is a linear combination of treatment means that sums to zero:
\[
L = \sum_{i=1}^{v} c_i \mu_i, \quad \text{with } \sum_{i=1}^{v} c_i = 0.
\]
This ensures we’re measuring relative differences. Examples:

Pairwise difference: \(\mu_1 - \mu_2\).
Comparison of groups: \(\frac{\mu_1 + \mu_2}{2} - \frac{\mu_3 + \mu_4}{2}\).

title: Comparisons and Contrasts
text:
Variance of a Contrast
If each treatment \(i\) has \(n_i\) observations and errors are \(N(0,\sigma^2)\), then:
\[
\text{Var}(L) = \sigma^2 \sum_{i=1}^v \frac{c_i^2}{n_i}.
\]
This variance helps form confidence intervals and tests for the contrast.

Example
In a battery life study with treatments A, B, C, D, suppose we suspect that (A and B) as a group differ from (C and D). We might form a contrast:
\[
L = \frac{\mu_A + \mu_B}{2} - \frac{\mu_C + \mu_D}{2}.
\]
This contrast directly tests a scientific hypothesis: Do the top two battery types outperform the bottom two on average?

title: Comparisons and Contrasts
text:
Fisher’s Least Significant Difference (LSD)

Conduct an ANOVA test first. If significant, proceed.
Compare pairwise means using the standard t-test but do not adjust alpha for multiple tests.
Pros: Simple, more powerful.
Cons: Higher chance of Type I errors when many comparisons are made.

title: Comparisons and Contrasts
text:
Tukey’s Honest Significant Difference (HSD)

Designed for pairwise comparisons.
Controls the family-wise error rate (FWER).
For equal sample sizes:

\[
\text{HSD} = q_{\alpha,v,n-v} \sqrt{\frac{\text{MSE}}{n}},
\]
where \(q\) is from the studentized range distribution.

title: Comparisons and Contrasts
text:
Bonferroni Method

Divide \(\alpha\) by the number of comparisons \(m\).
Very conservative for large \(m\).
Ensures strong control of FWER.

title: Comparisons and Contrasts
text:
Scheffé’s Method

Applies to any linear contrast, not just pairwise differences.
More general but often more conservative (wide confidence intervals).
Scheffé’s method is useful when the final set of contrasts is not fully decided a priori.

title: Comparisons and Contrasts
section: Example 1: Pairwise Comparisons with Tukey’s HSD
text:
Example 1: Pairwise Comparisons with Tukey’s HSD
Data Setup (Simulated):

set.seed(123)
data <- data.frame(
    Treatment = rep(c("A", "B", "C", "D"), each = 5),
    Response = c(rnorm(5, 10, 2), rnorm(5, 15, 2), rnorm(5, 20, 2), rnorm(5, 25, 2))
)

fit <- aov(Response ~ Treatment, data = data)
summary(fit)

            Df Sum Sq Mean Sq F value   Pr(>F)    
Treatment    3  631.3  210.43    47.7 3.33e-08 ***
Residuals   16   70.6    4.41                     
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

# Apply Tukey’s HSD if ANOVA is significant
TukeyHSD(fit)

  Tukey multiple comparisons of means
    95% family-wise confidence level

Fit: aov(formula = Response ~ Treatment, data = data)

$Treatment
         diff        lwr       upr     p adj
B-A  4.524222  0.7237295  8.324714 0.0170952
C-A 10.228663  6.4281709 14.029155 0.0000050
D-A 14.831544 11.0310518 18.632036 0.0000000
C-B  5.704441  1.9039494  9.504933 0.0028150
D-B 10.307322  6.5068303 14.107814 0.0000045
D-C  4.602881  0.8023889  8.403373 0.0151748



Interpretation

Look at the output: intervals that do not include zero indicate significant differences.
Tukey is effective for all pairs while maintaining the overall confidence level.

title: Comparisons and Contrasts
text:
Example 2: Testing a Specific Contrast
Defining a Contrast:

library(emmeans)

# Suppose we want to test (A,B) vs (C,D)
contrast_vec <- c(0.5, 0.5, -0.5, -0.5)

emm <- emmeans(fit, ~Treatment)
contrast(emm, method = list("AB_vs_CD" = contrast_vec))

 contrast estimate    SE df t.ratio p.value
 AB_vs_CD    -10.3 0.939 16 -10.932  <.0001



Interpretation
The output gives an estimate, standard error, t-value, and p-value. If p < alpha, we conclude there is evidence that (A,B) differ from (C,D).

title: Comparisons and Contrasts
text:
Medium Difficulty

Pairwise Comparisons: Given four treatments, run a simulation in R, fit an ANOVA, and use Tukey’s HSD. Interpret at least one pairwise comparison.
Constructing Contrasts: For three treatments (X, Y, Z), form a contrast comparing X with the average of Y and Z. Compute its variance using a known MSE and sample sizes.

title: Comparisons and Contrasts
text:
Challenging Problems

Scheffé’s Method for Arbitrary Contrasts: Generate data from five treatments and test a complex contrast (e.g., \((\mu_1+\mu_2)-(\mu_4+\mu_5)\)). Implement Scheffé’s method and interpret the wide confidence interval.
Power Analysis for MCPs: Using the pwr package in R, simulate a scenario with four treatments and known variance. Determine sample size needed to achieve 80% power under Tukey’s HSD for detecting a specified difference.

title: Comparisons and Contrasts
text:
References

Dean, A., Voss, D., & Draguljić, D. (2017). Design and Analysis of Experiments. Springer.
Montgomery, D. C. (2020). Design and Analysis of Experiments. Wiley.
Christensen, R. (2018). Analysis of Variance, Design, and Regression. Chapman and Hall/CRC.

title: Comparisons and Contrasts
text:
Proofs and Derivations

Variance of a Contrast
For a contrast \(L = \sum c_i \mu_i\), assuming independent samples of size \(n_i\) and variance \(\sigma^2\):
\[
\hat{L} = \sum c_i \bar{Y}_i, \quad \text{Var}(\hat{L}) = \sigma^2 \sum \frac{c_i^2}{n_i}.
\]
Proof involves linearity of expectation and variance properties under independence and homoscedasticity (Dean et al., 2017).


Derivation of Tukey’s HSD
Tukey’s HSD critical value is derived from the studentized range distribution \(q\):

Let \(\text{max diff} = \max_i(\bar{Y}_i) - \min_i(\bar{Y}_i)\).
Under \(H_0\), \(\frac{\text{max diff}}{\sqrt{\text{MSE}/n}}\) follows a studentized range distribution.
Invert this to find the critical range \(q_{\alpha,v,n-v}\).

(Montgomery, 2020)


Scheffé’s Method
Scheffé’s intervals are based on the fact that any linear contrast of treatment means can be bounded using a \((v-1)F\)-distribution multiplier:
\[
L \in \hat{L} \pm \sqrt{(v-1)F_{v-1, n-v,\alpha}}\cdot \text{SE}(\hat{L}).
\]
The proof uses the union-intersection principle and geometry of the parameter space (Christensen, 2018).

title: Course Syllabus - STAT 454/545
text:
Course Description
This course provides a rigorous introduction to experimental design and analysis of variance (ANOVA) methodologies, with an emphasis on their integration into linear modeling frameworks. Topics include fundamental principles of experimental design (randomization, replication, and blocking), handling unbalanced data, diagnostics for model assumptions, and advanced designs such as split-plot, nested, and mixed-effects models. Students will develop skills in designing experiments, selecting appropriate statistical approaches, analyzing data using R, and communicating findings effectively.

title: Course Syllabus - STAT 454/545
text:
Learning Outcomes
By the end of this course, students will be able to:

Design experiments using principles of randomization, replication, and blocking.
Implement one-way, two-way, and higher-order factorial ANOVA techniques.
Analyze unbalanced data using modern statistical methods.
Conduct residual analysis, transformations, and diagnostics for model assumptions.
Perform multiple comparisons and construct contrasts for treatment effect interpretation.
Incorporate covariates into ANOVA frameworks through analysis of covariance (ANCOVA).
Apply advanced designs like row–column, nested, and split-plot experiments.
Utilize statistical software (e.g., R) to perform experimental analyses and generate reproducible workflows.

Homework (50%)

Homework Submission Guidelines

Format and Template:
All homework assignments must be completed using the Quarto template provided on the course website. You are required to submit the rendered PDF version of the Quarto document. Failure to use the provided template or submit the correct format will result in point deductions.
Submission Platform:
Submit your completed assignments electronically through Canvas. Navigate to the “Assignments” folder, click on the appropriate homework assignment, and attach your rendered PDF file.
Plagiarism Check:
All submitted assignments will be automatically checked for plagiarism by Canvas. Any instances of plagiarism or academic dishonesty will be handled in accordance with UNM’s Student Code of Conduct and the Support in Receiving Help and Doing What is Right section outlined in this syllabus. Please familiarize yourself with the academic integrity policies detailed in the syllabus and on the UNM website. Ignorance of the policy is not an excuse for violations.
No Late Submissions Accepted:
All homework assignments are due by the specified deadline on Canvas. Late submissions will not be accepted under any circumstances. This policy is strict and applies to all students without exceptions.
Extra Credit Opportunity:
If you miss an assignment, you may compensate for it by earning extra credit as outlined in the syllabus. This provides an opportunity to recover points without requiring extensions or exceptions for missed deadlines.
Do Not Email About Late Assignments:
Please do not email me or the TA regarding missed or late homework submissions. We cannot make exceptions or accept late assignments under any conditions. Instead, focus on utilizing the extra credit opportunities provided in the syllabus.
Content Requirements:

All responses must be typed within the Quarto document.
If you include hand-written calculations or derivations, they must be scanned and appended to the Quarto document as an appendix before rendering the final PDF.

Independence:
All homework assignments must be completed independently. While collaboration in studying is encouraged, your final submission must reflect your own work.
Grading and Feedback:
Assignments will be graded and feedback will be provided through Canvas. Be sure to review comments and feedback promptly to address any misunderstandings before the next assignment.

Important Note: To avoid missing deadlines, plan your work carefully and submit your assignments early. If you are unfamiliar with Quarto or need assistance using the template, refer to the “Resources” section on Canvas for tutorials or contact me during office hours.

Exam Guidelines

Format: Exams are closed book but you may bring up to three double-sided cheat sheets (US Letter size) and a calculator. No other electronics or materials (e.g., books, lecture notes) are allowed.
Question Types: Includes a combination of short-answer questions, computations, and application-based problems.

No Make-Up Exams Policy

Make-up exams will only be granted in cases of proven emergency that meet the criteria set forth by the Department of Mathematics and Statistics and UNM policies (e.g., documented medical emergencies, official university-sponsored activities, or other unavoidable situations as defined by university guidelines).
If you anticipate a potential conflict or emergency, you must notify the instructor in advance of the exam date whenever possible. Failure to do so will result in forfeiture of the opportunity to take a make-up exam.
For non-emergency situations, personal conflicts, or reasons outside of those outlined in this document (e.g., vacation, workload, or personal oversight), make-up exams will not be permitted.

Proven Emergency Requirements:

Medical emergencies: Provide a signed note from a licensed healthcare provider explaining the need for absence.
University-sponsored activities: Submit official documentation from the relevant department.
Other emergencies: Submit verifiable proof (e.g., legal documentation, official notifications).

In all cases, documentation must be provided as soon as possible and must align with UNM’s student policies on academic integrity and attendance. For more information, consult the UNM Student Handbook: https://pathfinder.unm.edu.
Importance of Timely Notification
If you foresee a conflict or are unable to attend an exam due to an emergency, notify the instructor as early as possible. While advance notice does not guarantee a make-up exam, failing to provide notice will disqualify you from consideration for a make-up opportunity.
By adhering to this policy, we ensure fairness and consistency for all students while maintaining compliance with university guidelines. If you have further questions or concerns, please contact the instructor before the exam dates.


Extra Credit Opportunities
Students have the opportunity to earn up to 4% extra credit toward their final grade by completing the following tasks:
1. End-of-Semester Course Evaluation (Up to 3%)

Students who complete the end-of-semester course evaluation will receive up to 3% extra credit.

This quiz will assess familiarity with the syllabus and the course’s policies and expectations. Completing the quiz will earn 1% extra credit.
Note: The availability of this quiz may vary by semester and will be announced at the start of the course.

Important Notes:

These extra credit opportunities are designed to encourage engagement with the course policies and participation in university processes.
Extra credit is optional and cannot replace or make up for missed assignments, exams, or other coursework.
The maximum total extra credit available is 4%, which will be applied to your final grade at the end of the semester.
Students are encouraged to review the “Grading and Assessments” section of the syllabus to understand how extra credit impacts their overall grade.

Please take advantage of these opportunities to improve your final grade while reinforcing your understanding of the course and contributing to constructive course feedback.

title: Course Syllabus - STAT 454/545
section: What to Expect and How to Study and Be Successful in This Course
text:
What to Expect and How to Study and Be Successful in This Course
This course is designed to be both rigorous and rewarding, equipping you with essential skills in experimental design and analysis of variance (ANOVA). Success in this course requires preparation, consistent effort, and active engagement with the material. Below are some key recommendations and expectations to help you succeed:
1. Expect to Invest Significant Time

Mastery of the material requires dedicated study time each week. Plan to spend at least 8-10 hours per week outside of class on:
Reading assigned materials.
Completing homework assignments.
Practicing statistical techniques in R.
Reviewing notes and working through practice problems.

2. Prioritize Class Attendance

Attendance is critical to your success in this course.
Classes are designed to build upon each other, with cumulative content.
Discussions, group activities, and real-time problem-solving in class will reinforce your understanding.
Historical data has shown that students who miss class sessions struggle to keep up with the material.
If you must miss a class, review the lecture notes and course materials promptly, and reach out to classmates for additional support.

3. Come Prepared for Every Class

Read the assigned materials before class:
Familiarize yourself with the key topics to be covered.
Jot down questions or areas of confusion to bring to class discussions.
Engage with supplemental materials like videos, tutorials, or examples provided on Canvas.
Stay organized by keeping track of due dates, reading assignments, and planned lectures using the course schedule.

4. Stay Active During Class

Take detailed notes during lectures and participate in discussions.
Actively engage in group activities. Collaborating with classmates helps deepen your understanding and clarifies difficult concepts.
Ask questions during class or post them on Canvas if you need further clarification.

5. Utilize Office Hours and Discussion Boards

Office hours are an excellent opportunity for one-on-one assistance with:
Understanding difficult concepts.
Reviewing homework problems.
Discussing your specific challenges with course material.
Use the Canvas Discussion Boards for peer-to-peer support and quick clarifications from the instructor or TA.

6. Practice Regularly

Mastery of statistical methods requires consistent practice.
Work through examples provided in class and additional exercises from the textbook.
Attempt problems in R to solidify your understanding of statistical tools and software.

7. Review and Revise

After each class, set aside time to:
Review your notes.
Summarize key concepts in your own words.
Attempt practice problems to apply what you’ve learned.

8. Focus on Understanding, Not Memorization

This course emphasizes application and critical thinking.
Strive to understand the “why” behind statistical techniques and experimental designs.
Apply concepts to real-world scenarios or examples from your own field of study.

9. Manage Your Time Wisely

Start assignments early to avoid last-minute stress.
Break down large tasks into smaller steps and set achievable goals for each study session.
Use tools like planners or digital calendars to track deadlines and manage your workload effectively.

10. Maintain a Growth Mindset

Statistics can be challenging, but persistence is key.
Embrace mistakes as part of the learning process.
Reach out for help early if you’re struggling with a concept or assignment.

11. Make Use of the Resources Provided

The course provides several resources to support your learning:
A Quarto template for homework submissions.
Supplemental readings, videos, and tutorials.
Access to the course textbook through UNM’s library system.
R and VS Code or RStudio (or equivalent IDEs) for conducting statistical analyses.

12. Avoid Falling Behind

Given the cumulative nature of this course, falling behind on one topic will make subsequent topics more difficult to grasp.
Stay on top of assignments and make reviewing previous material part of your weekly routine.

13. Academic Honesty and Collaboration

While collaboration is encouraged during study sessions or discussions, ensure all submitted work reflects your own understanding.
Familiarize yourself with the Support In Receiving Help and Doing What is Right section of the syllabus to avoid issues related to academic dishonesty.

By following these recommendations, staying engaged, and managing your time wisely, you’ll position yourself for success in this course. Remember, learning statistics is a journey that requires consistent effort and a positive attitude. I am here to support you every step of the way, so don’t hesitate to reach out for assistance.

title: Tutorial on rep function in R
text:
The rep function in R replicates the elements of vectors. It is commonly used to:

Repeat single values or sequences.
Expand data sets with repetitive patterns.
Create predictable test cases for analysis or debugging.

It is a versatile function that supports various ways to replicate elements, making it a fundamental tool in data manipulation.



The rep function has the following arguments:

x:

Description: The vector to be replicated.
Type: Numeric, character, logical, or any other R object.
Required: Yes.
Examples:



rep(1:3, times = 2) # Output: 1 2 3 1 2 3

[1] 1 2 3 1 2 3



times:

Description: Specifies the number of times to repeat each element.
Type: Numeric vector (must be non-negative integers).
Default: None; must be explicitly defined if used.
Examples:



rep(1:3, times = c(2, 3, 1)) # Output: 1 1 2 2 2 3

[1] 1 1 2 2 2 3



each:

Description: Specifies the number of times to repeat each element individually.
Type: Numeric scalar (non-negative integer).
Default: 1.
Examples:



rep(1:3, each = 2) # Output: 1 1 2 2 3 3

[1] 1 1 2 2 3 3



length.out:

Description: Specifies the total length of the resulting vector.
Type: Numeric scalar.
Default: NULL (calculated based on other arguments).
Examples:



rep(1:3, length.out = 5) # Output: 1 2 3 1 2

[1] 1 2 3 1 2






Combining each and times:

When both each and times are specified, each operates first, followed by times.



rep(1:2, each = 2, times = 2) # Output: 1 1 2 2 1 1 2 2

[1] 1 1 2 2 1 1 2 2



Non-integer inputs:

Non-integer times, each, or length.out values are truncated to their integer part.



rep(1:2, times = 2.7) # Output: 1 1 2 2

[1] 1 2 1 2



Handling NA values:

Works seamlessly with vectors containing NA.



rep(c(NA, 1), each = 2) # Output: NA NA 1 1

[1] NA NA  1  1





Basic Usage:

# Repeat the sequence twice
rep(1:3, times = 2)

[1] 1 2 3 1 2 3

# Output: 1 2 3 1 2 3

Using each:

# Repeat each element twice
rep(1:3, each = 2)

[1] 1 1 2 2 3 3

# Output: 1 1 2 2 3 3

Custom Length:

# Truncate the output to a specific length
rep(1:3, length.out = 4)

[1] 1 2 3 1

# Output: 1 2 3 1

Combining each and times:

# A complex repetition pattern
rep(1:3, each = 2, times = 3)

 [1] 1 1 2 2 3 3 1 1 2 2 3 3 1 1 2 2 3 3

# Output: 1 1 2 2 3 3 1 1 2 2 3 3





Negative values for times or each:

Error: Error in rep.int: invalid 'times' argument
Fix: Ensure times and each are non-negative integers.



```{r}
#| eval: false

rep(1:3, times = -1) # Error
```


Mismatched lengths for times:

The times vector length must match x or be recycled appropriately.



```{r}
#| eval: false

rep(1:3, times = c(1, 2)) # Warning: longer object length is not a multiple of shorter object length
```


Non-numeric inputs:

Ensure that all arguments like length.out, each, and times are numeric.



```{r}
#| eval: false
rep(1:3, times = "two") # Error
```


Recycling:

If times or each is shorter than x, it generates an error.



```{r}
#| eval: false
rep(1:3, times = c(2, 3)) # Output: 1 1 2 2 2 3
```

title: Randomizing Treatments in R Using sample()
text:
The sample() function operates on vectors or integers and uses random number generation to produce randomized output.



x:

A vector of elements to sample from.
If x is a single positive integer, sample() assumes x as 1:x (i.e., the sequence from 1 to x).

size:

Specifies the number of elements to sample. Default is the length of x (i.e., it permutes the entire input if size is not specified).

replace:

Logical, determines if sampling is with replacement (TRUE) or without replacement (FALSE).
Default: FALSE.

prob:

A vector of weights for sampling probabilities. Weights are applied proportionally for sampling elements.
Default: NULL (uniform probabilities).

useHash (in sample.int):

Optimizes sampling for large datasets when replace = FALSE, prob = NULL, and size <= n/2.








Note



If replace = FALSE, size should not exceed the length of x. Otherwise, an error occurs.

title: Randomizing Treatments in R Using sample()
text:
The sample() function operates on vectors or integers and uses random number generation to produce randomized output.



x:

A vector of elements to sample from.
If x is a single positive integer, sample() assumes x as 1:x (i.e., the sequence from 1 to x).

size:

Specifies the number of elements to sample. Default is the length of x (i.e., it permutes the entire input if size is not specified).

replace:

Logical, determines if sampling is with replacement (TRUE) or without replacement (FALSE).
Default: FALSE.

prob:

A vector of weights for sampling probabilities. Weights are applied proportionally for sampling elements.
Default: NULL (uniform probabilities).

useHash (in sample.int):

Optimizes sampling for large datasets when replace = FALSE, prob = NULL, and size <= n/2.








Note



If replace = FALSE, size should not exceed the length of x. Otherwise, an error occurs.

title: Randomizing Treatments in R Using sample()
text:
Key Features

Random Permutation:

If no size is provided and replace = FALSE, the function shuffles all elements of x:



set.seed(42) # For reproducibility
sample(1:5)  # Outputs a random permutation, e.g., c(3, 5, 1, 4, 2)

[1] 1 5 4 3 2



With Replacement:

Allows sampling the same element multiple times:



sample(1:3, size = 5, replace = TRUE)  # Outputs, e.g., c(1, 3, 2, 2, 1)

[1] 2 2 1 3 3



Weighted Sampling:

Sampling based on a specified probability vector:



sample(1:3, size = 6, prob = c(0.1, 0.7, 0.2), replace = TRUE )  # Likely favors "2"

[1] 2 2 1 1 2 2



Default Behavior with Single Numeric x:

Treats x as 1:x:



sample(5)  # Equivalent to sample(1:5)

[1] 2 3 4 1 5



Edge Cases:

If size = 0 and x is empty or has length zero, the result is a zero-length vector.
Non-integer x or n is truncated to the nearest smaller integer.

title: Randomizing Treatments in R Using sample()
text:
Examples

1. Random Permutation

x <- c("A", "B", "C", "D")
sample(x)  # Randomly shuffles elements, e.g., c("C", "A", "D", "B")

[1] "C" "A" "D" "B"




2. Sampling With Replacement

sample(1:4, size = 6, replace = TRUE)

[1] 1 4 2 4 4 3

# Outputs, e.g., c(2, 4, 1, 3, 2, 4)



3. Weighted Sampling

sample(letters[1:5], size = 5, prob = c(0.5, 0.2, 0.1, 0.1, 0.1), replace = TRUE)

[1] "e" "a" "a" "d" "b"

# Heavily favors "a" in the output



4. Default Behavior for Single Integer

sample(5)  # Equivalent to sample(1:5)

[1] 3 5 2 4 1




5. Safeguarding Edge Cases with sample.int

# Programmatically handle edge cases for length(x) > 1:
resample <- function(x, ...) x[sample.int(length(x), ...)]

x <- 1:10
resample(x[x > 8])   # Properly handles cases where x has length < 2

[1] 10  9

resample(x[x > 10])  # Returns an empty vector safely

integer(0)

title: Randomizing Treatments in R Using sample()
text:
Best Practices

Reproducibility: Use set.seed() to ensure reproducible randomization:


set.seed(42)
sample(1:5)

[1] 1 5 4 3 2



Edge Cases: Use sample.int for numeric sequences, especially in programmatic contexts, to avoid surprises with default sample() behavior.
Weight Verification: Ensure that weights in prob are non-negative and not all zero.
Large Dataset Efficiency: Use useHash (via sample.int) for large n to optimize memory and performance.
